content.body: I think I have more complaining hsivonen to do again :-)
Oh hey, no, it looks like Hixie just didn't label the appropriate commits
No... I totally can yell at him ^_^
I'm pretty sure the spec doesn't deal with </x x x> yet
nvm again
I'm confused... does that mean that we can have naughty characters in our HTML5 documents?
Huh, I guess so
Oh god, 105 test-cases to fix
Ruh oh... can't actually express \u10FFFF in JSOn
Haha, whoo surrogates
numericEntities: aggh
I wonder where the script we used to generate this was
ezyang: you testing surrogate handling?
Uhh, sort of
So Hixie landed a change to the spec which implies that crazy stuff like that should get passed through without harm
But that doesn't have any legal surrogates...
I think I should send him mail about this
ezyang: aside from lone surrogates, the weirdo characters that can now be used as numeric references were already available if you used them as UTF-8 in the raw stream
UTF-8 doesn't even have a mechanism for building something that long...
ezyang: what were you about to complain to me about?
It was my fault; after double checking with the spec all of your changes were correct.
ezyang: UTF-8 can build code points until 0x10FFFF just fine
ok
On an unrelated note, have you looked at r3374?
of the spec?
Yeah
looks
ezyang: the changes to the Windows-1252 table are questionable, but I'm not sure if they are what existing browsers do
"If the number is in the range 0x0001 to 0x0008" ... "error" is good
so, the C1 range stuff I'd have to double-check, but the rest is good
what's the right way to convert a single-character string to the number corresponding to the code point in JS_
charCodeAt
http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/saved/159
have to wait for Windows to boot to have a verdict...
hsivonen: The interesting bit is how error handling changed
Instead of replacing it with U+FFFD, we pass it through.
This results in hilarity with large numeric entities
ezyang: larger than 0x10FFFF?
yep
ezyang: I think numericEntities.test and unicodeChars.test were generated by me with a Perl script that I might have not uploaded anywhere
oh. those should still becode U+FFFD
Yep
if the spec now says otherwise, it's a bug
I wrote a script to convert them, so don't worry about it
Well, Hixie very deliberately changed it to match browser behavior
ezyang: what's browser behavior for > 0x10FFFF?
Firefox simply ignores the character
that's not good
Don't have access to other browsers at the moment
oops, i thought i'd already made > 10FFFF get not parsed as a charref
I thought Firefox wrapped values larger than 2^32
I could have missed that cluedump
webkit treats � as &#x110000;
not great, either
Hixie: I dropped you mail about it, ftr
hrm. my test case isn't working in IE at all
thanks
It's way past my bedtime. Let me know what we decide :-)
it's on my pile
my latency is about a month right now
how do I get the DOMString out of a text node in IE?
it's been a long time since I've written IE workaround JS
.data
thanks
no, that's not it
nodeValue is supposed to be a prop on the object...
hmm. does IE go crazy if a node value contains a bad character?
nope. that's not the reason
something is going badly wrong in my testing in IE
I feel clueless
anyway, whatever IE does, it's not mapping the unmapped characters of Windows-1252 C1 range to U+FFFD
.data definitely gets you the text out of Text node in IE last i checked
Opinions on https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=503210 for Web DOM Core?
re bug, no opinion. what's the use case?
Hixie: I'm failing to get even innerHTML out of an element or .length out of a text node in Live DOM Viewer in IE
have you tried with just regular text?
maybe their serialiser is barfing
Hixie: serializing any DOM as a JS script that recreates the DOM
Hixie: I tried with 'a'
Hixie: same result, which is weird
what's the use case for serializing any DOM as a JS script that recreates the DOM?
odd
Hixie: fuzzing
so testing? not a platform feature?
does the innerHTML part of the live dom viewer itself work?
Hixie: yes
then i dunno what's going on
hsivonen: did you implement the spec or webkit behaviour for table taint in the html5.parser?
Hixie: WebKit behavior
anything to report?
nothing regarading Web compat regarding taint to report
hsivonen: which version of IE?
the only problems have been with Gecko-only test suites
the only taint problems that is
jgraham: IE8 on Windows XP SP3
hsivonen: AFAICT IE8 is broken in the live dom viewer
At least for me on windows 7
jgraham: well, it's broken in a really subtle way
because I can w() the text node object
hsivonen:
er
hsivonen: k
hsivonen: oh. Well the whole w() function is broken for me

i guess i'll make dodo do dodo
parse as "dodo do dodo" instead of "do do do do do" tomorrow then
Hixie: nice
not really, but it's hard to argue with your points :-)
the list of things in html5 i disagree with is growing quite long

Hi, imagine a category tree structure and you are to select a category for your article, how would you do that? <select> with nested <optgroup>s seems to be an interesting idea but you cannot select XYZ category marked up with label="XYZ category" because it is, well, a label. I looked into the archives, saw some mails about it, but the spec is silent about this...
Mrmil: <select>/<option> with indentation of the option text to indicate nesting?
(That doesn't seem very nice but I guess it sort of works)
Philip`: Yeah, we're currently using that, but I don't think it's too accessible. If the optgroup mechanism was capable of doing it, it would be awesome

wonders if something like <details><legend><input type=radio>Category</legend><details><legend><input type=radio>Sub-category</legend><input type=radio>Sub-sub-category</details></details> would be appropriate semantics
(plus some <label>s or whatever)
looks quite interesting...
wonders if "slut" in Shane's blog URL triggered the "courtesy preview" on tinyarro.ws
http://blog.halindrome.com/2009/07/w3c-you-ignorant-slut.html?showComment=1247069810064#c2703275792180082243
Shane seems to think that walled garden
+s are worth supporting explicitly
and presumably worth supporting as first-class citizens of the language, rather than using <div class> and data-* attributes or similar extensibility mechanisms
I'm not sure I take people seriously who come out with statements like "[HTML 5 is a] bloated monstrosity that already kills the battery on your phone"
I'm not sure I take people seriously who answer "why modularise a spec?" with "because modularisation itself is the benefit"

though I guess the answer was also "because of the mindset behind it", but that seems to be to be someone who aims for theoretical purity and would probably be unsuited to actually editing HTML5 in a way that wasn't theoretically pure
finds https://www.psd2html.com/order-now.html ISO 9001-certified.
jgraham: Seems to be a strange and not entirely coherent mixture of complaining about the size of the language and complaining about the size of the single-page specification
oh, I saw that post and I didn't notice that was Shane McCarron's blog
hsivonen: Someone should tell them they're allowed to write more than one line of code per <script>
takkaria: It sounds to me like the mindset is about allowing extensibility, not about theoretical purity
notes it was jax from Opera who brought up phone batteries
you could split HTML5 up into multiple modules and not have any more extension points than you have now, though
takkaria: or you could have prescribed extension points as in XHTML M12N but the wrong points
(see XHTML MP)
wonders who jax is, then finds http://my.opera.com/jax/blog/2009/07/07/an-xhtml-2-far

takkaria: Indeed, which is why the important thing is the mindset behind M12N (of providing well-defined extensibility points that are on an equal footing to the HTML markup itself) and not the mechanism of splitting the spec into modules
Philip`: jax is Jonny Axelsson
Opera employee
or former one now, maybe
MikeSmith: I figured that out after finding his blog :-)
former?
hasn't read the blog yet
hsivonen: I'm not sure if he still works for Opera
sees "now that I don't work for Opera anymore"
hadn't heard much about/for him for a long time
about/from
I wonder who he does work for
he was living in Prague still, I think
is living in Praque, has been for a few years now
JohnResig, yt?

http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/?%3C!DOCTYPE%20html%3E%0D%0A%3Cstyle%3E%0D%0A.a%20%7B%20-o-link%3A%20attr(href)%3B%20-o-link-source%3A%20next%3B%20%7D%0D%0A.b%20%7B%20-o-link%3A%20attr(href)%3B%20-o-link-source%3A%20current%3B%20%7D%0D%0A%3C%2Fstyle%3E%0D%0A%3Cp%20class%3D%22a%22%20href%3D%22javascript%3Aalert(1)%22%3EClick%20me%0D%0A%3Cp%20class%3D%22b%22%20href%3D%22javascript%3Aalert(2)%22%3EClick%20me%0D%0A
Uh, http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/saved/160
I never knew Opera did that
JohnResig, I'm just wondering if you've had a chance to work on the selectors api test suite yet.
Philip`, what does -o-link-source do?
guesses it sets rel or something
I can report that, of the bits of HTML5 we have implemented so far, none seem to be particularly bad for phone battery
Lachy: It makes the element into a link, using the -o-link of the current or next element (or something like that)
(In that example, both lines use the href from the second line)
ok
Hmm, maybe 'next' chooses the next element (in tree order) that has -o-link
so you could e.g. say ... or whatever
(to make the whole cell into a link)
thinks he ought to set up some wiki for himself
But I already treat my blog like a wiki in a lot of ways
gsnedders: Do you have edit wars with yourself?
Philip`: Rarely, just constantly building upon what I wrote earlier
gsnedders: Do you mindlessly vandalise your pages?
It's not sounding much like a wiki at all
Philip`: Have you /read/ gsnedders poetry?
jgraham: No :-p
jgraham: in parts I agree with the mindless. I'm not sure whether it's really vandalism though.
I like to think of it as mindless vandalism of the mind
Oh, but my mind was already mindlessly vandalised before writing them.
grr. why have my GWT Eclipse launch configs become unlauchable...
Lachy: hey, I haven't had a chance yet - I've needed to finish up some other things before moving on to that
Lachy: it's on my list, hoping to tackle it very soon
ok
does anyone happen to know how to make Eclipse re-acknowledge the ".launch" file name extension?
Safari with <!-- a --   !> is interesting
hsivonen, i *think* you can just assign file associations in General -> Editors -> File Associations
heh. IE8 has the same comment buffer trimming strategy I implemented as opposed to what Hixie specced, except they haven't been careful enough with edge cases to hide the impl. details
Upon >, they trim the accumulated buffer by two from the end
pesla: can't find a way to associate it with launching as opposed to an editor :-(
aargh. I broke livedom.validator.nu
wow. Glazman blog rendering prked in latest Minefield
http://www.glazman.org/weblog/
on Linux at least, in my environment
sayrer: you awake?
in my minefield, glazou looks like this:
http://people.w3.org/mike/gecko/glazou.png
MikeSmith: WFM using a recentish build with html5.enable
on linux
OK
Oh, my build seems to be way more out of date than I thought
this is with very latest minefield -- today or yesterday
and same thing with html5.enabled false
jgraham, doesn't Minefield do automatic updates for you every day?
MikeSmith: I see the problem - the text is yucky and un-antialiased :-(
Lachy: you can turn that auto-update thing off
Philip`: good eye!
MikeSmith, ok. Why would you, though?
Lachy: because it's stupid?
is that a question or a statement?
Lachy: It offers to upgrade every day but I often ignore it
Lachy: are you asking or making a suggestion?
Are we playing questions?
Mine automatically downloads the updates and installs them whenever I restart.
tries to write Ruby
gsnedders: Which kind of Ruby?
gsnedders, that's a very short word to write, but well done. You succeeded.
Didn't Lachy just lose?
ph
Philip`: The shiny one
jgraham, we were playing a game?
gsnedders: Animal, vegetable, or mineral?
Philip`, Animal
Philip`: The shiny one.
So gsnedders is writing a Ruby that is a shiny animal?
Yes.
(And I'm saying that just because Hixie can't, because he says he never lies)
Couldn't that be a lie?
Hah! No wonder he's doing so well at controlling the future of the intarwebs!
is <b> and <i> actually going to be left in html5?
Why wouldn't they be?

seems they is all ready represented by <strong> for example. And it doesn't seem to be a good example for when to use them. Or why would the specs say this: "In the previous example, the correct element to use would have been strong, not b."?
uhm... nevermind that quote :)
eighty4, http://lachy.id.au/log/2007/05/b-and-i
Lachy: thanks :D
Lachy: but given there definition how is the names of them motivated? <aside>, <article> and so on describes their intended use. How does <b> describe it's use? Or isn't that important?
eighty4: how does b not describe it's intended use?
Sorry if I'm bringing up already discussed stuff. Haven't read up on my html5 :/

So I have a problem. I have a test harness which loads testcases into an iframe. It is not impossible that those testcases will cause infinite loops or other bad behaviour so it would be nice to be able to set a timeout and kill the script if the timeout is reached
Howwever this doesn't seem to be easy; the event loop seems to prioritise running the existing script above anything else.
(run to completion I guess)
eighty4, b is intended for use cases which are commenly represented typographically in bold text, but for which no specific semantic element exists
eighty4, it would be unreasonable to have to create separate semantic elements to individually cover each of those cases, when it wouldn't gain any benefit over using the generic element
Is there some way I force the source of the iframe to change before the testcase script has finished running?
similarly for the i element
beowulf: from what I understand it's not intended to represent bold text but rather like Lachy just wrote "text usually written in bold"
(or close the window with the iframe in or delete the iframe or something, as long as it causes the script to die)
eighty4, the names are retained for backwards compatibility reasons. It's best not to read too much into just the name of the element. It's the definition that matters mose
Lachy: that explanation was good :) Not sure I'm agreeing with you but still.
jgraham: I'm guessing that setTimeout() isn't being your friend
jgraham, I don't know of any way to achieve that, unless perhaps setting the iframe's window.location to a new page interrupts any scripts running within the iframe
Lachy: I got that backward compatiblility reason :) Just not a big fan of that either.
eighty4, it's really just a matter of being pragmatic over theoretical purity
Lachy: setting the <iframe>.src doesn't
Lachy: have nothing to do today and haven't been reading much about html5 so I'm catching up.
I'm not intending to start an argument
jgraham, what about iframe.contentWindow.location?
Lachy: OK I will try it
eighty4, no worries. You've been much more pleasant and understanding than the person I debated this with over twitter 2 days ago
Lachy: I'm not really bothered with html5 having it, but I can imagine it being missused.
indeed. It will be.
I'm not sure it makes any difference if it's "misused"
the idea that <strong> is more accessible than <b> in any way is a red herring
takkaria: but <b> will still give bold text I assume?
well, yeah
just like <strong> does
true
they are equivalent on the vast mojority of pages
except those select few which change default styling for either
mutters about how badly designed the 'this' semantics are in javascript
Hmm, deleting the iframe seems to work well
takkaria: but still, <strong> have semantic meaning while <b> doesn't. From what I understand
they both have meaning
* just not as clear semantic meaning then :)
I'm not sure <strong> has a particularly clear meaning either
it have a better meaning for me at least. But that doesn't really say anything
they're basically synonyms, discussing which one is "better" seems to be a waste of everyone's time
I seem to have acquired a stronger view on this than I used to have. :)
i've developed the strong view that it just doesn't matter
takkaria: I'm doing my best on wasting my time on meanless stuff right now. Third day on my "time off"
I really wish people had never used the word "semantic" in conjunction with the web, "meaning" is much less opaque and you couldn't get consturctions like "semantic meaning"
But I'll stop bothering you now
eighty4, without <i>, which element would you use to mark up a ship name, which is conventionally rendered in italics?
Lachy: <title>, <name> or something similar. But yes. It would be a challange to figure out what that element should be named
so you're advocating creating a new element for each case like that?
even though there are potentially dozens of such cases?
no, not really. Haven thought about it that much
It just feels like there should be a better name for <i> then i
but I guess there isn't
a better name for representating traditioanlly italicised text than "italic"? :)
it seems there should ba a name for the italic "meaning"
*should be
doesn't like his new espresso.
I should buy new

Reading Shelly's latest on www-archive, it seems she prefers to work under the assumption that Microsoft isn't acting in good faith and has convinced her self that they're going to object to everything as soon as we try to go to LC
I really wish people would stop referring to HTML5 as "the spec to build a browser"
takkaria, indeed, it's not just for browsers
and you need a lot more to build a browser, like http and css
given that I refer to it fairly often when writing JS, I think it's a wholly inaccurate title given only to rile people
hsivonen: ping
takkaria: But do you understand the event loop?
Does anyone (apart from H) understand the event loop!?
hsivonen: are you aware of any remaining gecko figure/legend issues with new parser?    i'm  looking into 1...perhaps just some default stylesheet additions needed still
I'm kind of curious to know if anyone is using php html5lib
ezyang: Add some code to it that pings a URL whenever someone runs the library
Har har har :-P
That's what the Python one does
Wait, are you serious?
That's not actually acceptable.
is rarely serious :-)
reads the htmlwg minutes and wonders if maybe it could be a prerequisite that people who ask for changes to html5 actually read it first
or at least the relevant sections
Hixie, which points in the telcon minutes are you referring to?
Hixie: what fun would that be?
I'm very surprised by Joshue's outright rejection of my rather practical proposal for making that particular use of canvas accessible.
